title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: [ONLINE]- Introduction to Network analysis in R  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi, everybody!
We hope that you and your family are doing well. We are super excited to have Jill de Ron, PhD student at the psychological methods department of the University of Amsterdam (UvA) to bring you a workshop on Network analysis in R!

DESCRIPTION
-------------------
We can use networks to provide insights into a variety of settings: A network connecting our Facebook friends gains understanding in our social structure; a human contact network gains insight into disease transmission; and a network of public transport lines informs us about the most central subway stations. In these examples, the relationships between components in the network are known. But in a lot of other cases, the relationships between components are unknown and are what we are interested in. For example, when we want to investigate the relationships between different personality traits. Network psychometrics makes it possible to estimate relationships between a large number of variables. Once you estimated a network, you can perform network-based statistics that give you information about the network’s local and global characteristics. In this workshop, you will learn how to estimate, analyze and interpret (psychological) network models. After a short introduction to network models, we will follow by a tutorial on analyzing data with network models.

PROGRAMME
----------------------
18.30- 18.45 Virtual Welcome
18.45- 20.30 Workshop and Q&A

ABOUT JILL
-------------------
I am a PhD student at the psychological methods department of the University of Amsterdam (UvA). My research is concerned with computational models of anxiety disorders and (formal) theory construction in psychology. I have a master’s degree in both Behavioral Data Science and Psychology. During my master programs I have been teaching assistant for the network analysis course at the UvA.

PREREQUISITES
-----------------------
A basic knowledge of R is recommended. To join the tutorial, please install the bootnet package and the qgraph package.

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore: R-Ladies Baltimore -- An introduction to the R/Bioconductor Ecosystem (Virtual)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

The next event is Thursday January 28, 2021 from 3-4:30pm (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have an exciting presentation from Jocelyn Chavez (https://josschavezf.netlify.app) a Ph.D. student at the Biotechnology Institute-UNAM in Mexico! She will give an introduction to the R/Bioconductor (http://bioconductor.org) ecosystem, using Bioconductor packages, contributing packages, how to get help, attending the annual conference, and also sharing her experience with Bioconductor in general. If you haven't heard of Bioconductor, you can think of it like a cousin to CRAN, but for the analysis of biological data.

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & want to know more about what is Bioconductor!
- If you work with biological data in R, but are unfamiliar with Bioconductor!
- If you are interested contributing to Bioconductor to analyze biological data!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. She will give a presentation on two R packages: matahari (https://github.com/jhudsl/matahari) and tidycode (https://lucymcgowan.github.io/tidycode/). The matahari package is a simple package for tidy logging of everything you type into the R console. title: R-Ladies San Diego: Course: Modeling Normally Distributed Data with Repeated Measures  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hey R-Ladies SD members,

This short course is being hosted by OCRUG on Zoom and they have kindly invited us to participate.

There is a nominal cost, but they would like all to attend who want to. So there are a number of free tickets available. Just email [masked] for details.

The event details provided by OCRUG are as follows:

Registration is on Eventbrite (https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ocrug-modeling-normally-distributed-data-with-repeated-measures-tickets-135236340535).

Abstract
This workshop will give you the practical skills and foundational knowledge to effectively use some powerful regression models used by data scientists. When data are collected on the same subjects repeatedly over time (for example, in clinical trials or cohort studies) or under different conditions (for example, in a designed experiment), the measurements within the same individual are modeled as having correlated values. At the workshop, we will consider several models that can be employed to model a normally distributed response variable. The models that we will consider are: random slope and intercept (mixed-effects) model and generalized estimating equations models with unstructured, autoregressive, compound symmetric (exchangeable), and independent working correlation matrices. All models will be run in R version 4.0.3.

The course will be structured as follows. For each part, we will first discuss the theory, then work through an example. After that, the participants will work in small groups in break-out rooms to do hands-on exercises to help reinforce the material. All the files and Rstudio will be made available to the participants.

We would like to use the RStudio Cloud. If you are not familiar with this technology, the participants use a web browser to access RStudio. The environment will be set up and loaded with the code and data that is needed. This way, participants can focus on building models.

The material covered by the workshop will be taken from my recently published book ["Advanced Regression Models with SAS and R Applications"](https://www.amazon.com/dp/1138049018/), CRC Press, 2018.

About the Instructor
Dr. Olga Korosteleva, is a professor of Statistics at the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at California State University, Long Beach (CSULB). She received her Bachelor's degree in Mathematics in 1996 from Wayne State University in Detroit, and a Ph.D. in Statistics from Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana, in 2002. Since then she has been teaching mostly Statistics courses in the Master's program in Applied Statistics at CSULB, and loving it!

Dr. Olga is an undergraduate advisor for students majoring in Mathematics with an option in Statistics. She is also the faculty supervisor for the Statistics Student Association. She is also the immediate past-president of the Southern California Chapter of the American Statistical Association (SCASA). Dr. Olga is the editor-in-chief of SCASA's monthly eNewsletter and the author (co-author) of four statistical books.

Schedule

• 06:30-06:40 Introduction
• 06:40-07:30 Mixed-effects Model for Normal Response
• 07:30-07:50 Mixed-effects Model Exercise
• 07:50-08:00 Mixed-effects Model Solution
• 08:00-08:10 Break
• 08:10-08:30 Generalized Estimating Equations (GEE) Model for Normal Response
• 08:30-08:50 GEE Exercise
• 08:50-09:00 GEE Solution
• 09:00-09:30 Additional Exercise and Solution
• 09:30-09:45 Wrap up

We hope to see you all there!

Your R-Ladies SD organizers

title: EdinbR: The Edinburgh R Usergroup: February 2021: unintended consequences of machine learning and Shiny Nirvana  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
description:
Hi everyone!

The second session of 2021 will be on February 17th, join us from 5.30pm online! As usual, the meeting will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome.

Our online meetings are kindly being enabled by Red Hat (https://www.redhat.com/). In order to join us you need to register with MeetUp (https://www.meetup.com/EdinbR/).

Our speakers are Dave Evans and Eric Nantz.

* **Dave Evans** (https://twitter.com/dlesomewhere) was the first data scientist at FreeAgent and currently leads the data science and analytics teams. Before joining FreeAgent, Dave worked at the University of California, San Diego and CERN.

* **Eric Nantz** (https://twitter.com/theRcast) is a principal research scientist at a large life sciences company, creating innovative analytical pipelines and capabilities supporting study designs and analyses. Outside of his day job, Eric is passionate about connecting with the R community as the creator/host of the R-Podcast, Shiny Developer Series, and the recently-launched R Weekly Highlights podcast.

---

## The unintended consequences of machine learning: detecting nonsense with a markov model

### Dave Evans
In this talk I'll discuss how I created a transition matrix from character data to filter fraudulent signups to our web application and illustrate how using machine learning can easily introduce unwanted biases.

---

## The New Roads Leading to Shiny Nirvana

### Eric Nantz

Since its first release over eight years ago, the R community has progressively created amazing web-based applications with the Shiny package. In practically every R conference or user meetup, we see amazing examples of how Shiny is changing the landscape of data exploration and sophisticated production pipelines. Have you ever wondered just how these amazing applications came to be, and what tools you can use to carve your own Shiny journey? In this talk I will shine a spotlight on the latest books addressing best practices in application development, and how they opened tremendous possibilities in both my professional and open-source Shiny projects.

---

See you there!

/federico

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Algorithms of Oppression  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Algorithms of Oppression (https://www.bookdepository.com/Algorithms-Oppression-Safiya-Umoja-Noble/9781479837243).

A revealing look at how negative biases against women of color are embedded in search engine results and algorithms

Run a Google search for "black girls"-what will you find? "Big Booty" and other sexually explicit terms are likely to come up as top search terms. But, if you type in "white girls," the results are radically different. The suggested porn sites and un-moderated discussions about "why black women are so sassy" or "why black women are so angry" presents a disturbing portrait of black womanhood in modern society.

In Algorithms of Oppression, Safiya Umoja Noble challenges the idea that search engines like Google offer an equal playing field for all forms of ideas, identities, and activities. Data discrimination is a real social problem; Noble argues that the combination of private interests in promoting certain sites, along with the monopoly status of a relatively small number of Internet search engines, leads to a biased set of search algorithms that privilege whiteness and discriminate against people of color, specifically women of color.

Through an analysis of textual and media searches as well as extensive research on paid online advertising, Noble exposes a culture of racism and sexism in the way discoverability is created online. As search engines and their related companies grow in importance-operating as a source for email, a major vehicle for primary and secondary school learning, and beyond-understanding and reversing these disquieting trends and discriminatory practices is of utmost importance.

An original, surprising and, at times, disturbing account of bias on the internet, Algorithms of Oppression contributes to our understanding of how racism is created, maintained, and disseminated in the 21st century.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Tidy Tuesday with R-Ladies DC: Galentine's Day Special Event  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This is the next event in our Tidy Tuesday series, even though it's happening on a Saturday. 😅

Tidy Tuesday (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) is an open-source weekly data science adventure through all things R and tidyverse. (https://www.tidyverse.org/)

In honor of Galentine's Day, we're going to gather and celebrate our R-Lady skills by having a virtual show-and-tell event using Tidy Tuesday data.

Your task (if you choose to accept it) is to create a data visualization or data analysis to share with the group using the Tidy Tuesday data that is released the week of Feb. 9th (or another Tidy Tuesday data set). We'll take turns showing off our code and results.

This will be a free-flowing and fun event! (BYO Mimosas 😉) There's no pressure to bring any analysis/visualization at all, but we encourage everyone to give it a try! If you're new to R or the {tidyverse}, one of the best ways to learn is to Just Do It, as Nike says.

Since this is a new type of R-Ladies DC event, we are experimenting with different times and formats until we finalize what we want these hangouts to look like.

We can't wait to see you there with all your Valentine's to the {tidyverse}! ❤️

title: Dublin R: #GlobalR: {ggstatsplot}- Creating {ggplot2}-Based Plots With Statistical Details, Ireland, Europe
description:
This event is organized by the Oslo useR! meetup group: https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/events/275861577

[Abstract]
{ggstatsplot} is an extension of the {ggplot2} package for creating
graphics with details from statistical tests, included in the information-rich plots themselves.
In a typical exploratory data analysis workflow, data visualization and statistical modeling are two different phases: visualization informs modeling, and modeling in turn can suggest a different visualization method, and so on and so forth.
The central idea of {ggstatsplot} is simple: combine these two phases into one in the form of graphics with statistical details, which makes data exploration simpler and faster!

[Bio]
Indrajeet Patil is a Postdoctoral Researcher at the Center for Humans and Machines, Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Berlin. He has a Ph.D. in cognitive neuroscience and specializes in investigating the psychological and neural basis of moral judgment and decision-making. He is also an active R package developer and part of the {easystats} team.

description:
For this meetup Seattle UseR Group is pleased to give an opportunity for its members to hear from Emily Robinson and Dr. Jacqueline Nolis on their new book "Building a Career in Data Science".

Emily Robinson is a senior data scientist at Warby Parker, where she works on a centralized team tackling some of the company's projects. She previously worked at DataCamp, where she built and ran their experimentation analytics system, and at Etsy, where she worked with their search team.

Dr. Jacqueline Nolis is a data science leader with over 15 years of experience in leading data science teams and projects at companies ranging from DSW to Airbnb. She has a PhD in Industrial Engineering, and for fun Jacqueline likes to use data science for humor - like using deep learning to generate offensive license plates.

Authors Emily and Jaqueline will read selections from their book and discuss why parts were personally meaningful and tell stories from their pasts that ended up shaping the narrative. You’ll learn about the overarching themes from the book to help people excel in their data science careers, as well as tips that can be practical for people at all career levels. After Emily and Jacqueline discuss their book, the floor will open so anyone can ask their data science career questions.

title: R-Ladies RTP: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

This month we will be analyzing data from the Kenya Census which is brought to us by Shelmith Kariuki, a co-organizer of NairobiR. https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2021/2021-01-19/readme.md

Agenda:
7:00 - 7:15 pm Meet & Greet
7:15 - 8:30 pm #tidytuesday
8:30 - 9:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a cozy beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: R-Ladies RTP: ggplot Basics  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Details
This workshop event will focus on the basics of data visualization using the ggplot R package. We will explore general ggplot syntax, common graph types, and editing graphs to improve visualization effectiveness. This event is intended for beginner R users who have not worked with ggplot before or would like to refresh their skills in the basics of ggplot syntax.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Agenda:
• 7:00pm - 7:15pm - Introductions
• 7:15pm - 8:00pm - Guided workshop
• 7:30pm - 7:50pm - Test your skills with a new example
• 8:20m - 8:30pm - Wrap up

**Before you join**, please install the most recent version of R **as well as** RStudio on your computer before attending this meetup event. Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep to our schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

If you have trouble installing the software, please contact Sheila at [masked] at least 48 hours **before the event** so we can find a time to meet and work through software installation issues.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

title: R-Ladies CDMX: Expresiones regulares para la limpieza y transformación de datos  [Virtual] , Mexico, Latin America
description:
Tal como prometimos el año pasado, este viernes repetiremos el taller sobre expresiones regulares para la limpieza y transformación de datos que realizamos el año pasado en el marco de LatinR (https://latin-r.com), la conferencia Latinoamericana sobre uso de R en investigación y desarrollo. En esta ocasión, se llevará a cabo en dos sesiones (los viernes 12 y 19 de febrero), para poder cubrir los contenidos con mayor profundidad. El taller estará a cargo de Stephanie Orellana (https://twitter.com/sporella) y Riva Quiroga (https://twitter.com/rivaquiroga).
- SOBRE EL TALLER
Este taller tiene por objetivo que sus participantes se familiaricen con el uso de expresiones regulares (conocidas también como "regex"). Específicamente, abordaremos el potencial que tienen como parte del proceso de limpieza y transformación de datos usando paquetes del Tidyverse.
Los ejemplos prácticos se enfocarán en el trabajo con dataframes y archivos de texto, y en cómo utilizar expresiones regulares en conjunto con funciones de los paquetes {stringr}, {dplyr} y {tidyr}.
- REQUERIMIENTOS
Para este taller es necesario tener una versión de R igual o superior a 3.6 y tener instalados RStudio y los paquetes {tidyverse}, {janitor} y la versión en desarrollo de {datos}.
Esta última se puede instalar desde GitHub con: remotes::install_github("cienciadedatos/datos").
El taller se dictará a través de la plataforma Zoom. Media hora antes del evento enviaremos la clave de acceso a la reunión.
- SOBRE LA SEGUNDA SESIÓN
La segunda sesión de este taller se llevará a cabo el viernes 19 de febrero. Para asistir, debes inscribirte en el evento correspondiente, que quedará publicado acá en Meetup a principios de la próxima semana.
- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
¡Te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies Seattle: Tutorial: Introduction to Parallel Processing in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us for a lunchtime R-Ladies meetup with Brittany Barker. Brittany will guide us through a beginner-level tutorial on how and why to use parallel computing in R.

Brittany is a Research Associate (Postdoc) at the Oregon IPM Center at Oregon State University, where she is developing a spatial modeling platform (written in R) that predicts phenology and climate suitability of invasive insect species in real-time. She is broadly interested in how environmental perturbations such as climate change shape the population dynamics and geographical range limits of plant and animal species.

In her demo, she will demonstrate the use and value of the parallel, doParallel, and foreach packages for parallel computing in R. The demo will center on analyzing very large spatial data sets, but parallel processing in R can be used for ANY type of data. She will provide examples of when you may want to use parallel computing for your work, and provide further resources to explore.

This demo will be held over zoom and we will RStudio Cloud so you can follow along with the Brittany's code. We will email out instructions on what to expect and how to get set up.

~~How to follow Brittany’s tutorial:~~

**Recommended** Option 1: Create a free RStudio Cloud account and join Brittany’s shared workspace using the link below. This will create a copy of Brittany’s R project for you and allow to run her code. The advantage of using RStudio Cloud is that all of the packages you will need are pre-installed and you’ll be working from the same settings as Brittany. This will make it much easier for us to help you if you run into any problems.
https://rstudio.cloud/spaces/119389/join?access_code=412mjNHj6%2BJmLjN24nM8Px6UDtq7qILJh%2B064Io2

Option 2: If you don’t want to use RStudio Cloud, you can clone Brittany’s repo. You will need to install the R packages ahead of time. (Note: you will not be able to run the entire RMD file on your own computer unless you are using a Unix based OS.)
https://github.com/bbarker505/parallel_demo

If you want to watch the presentation and not run the code in real time, that is also fine.

Please reach out if you have any questions (email: [masked]).

title: CinDay RUG: My experience with Topic Modeling (Virtual)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hello,

It’s time for another meeting. This time I will be presenting a follow up from my January 2020 presentation on sentiment analysis. Since it was a long time ago, I will briefly go over last year’s presentation followed by a presentation on my experience with Topic Modeling.

What is topic modeling? Here is one explanation:

We often have collections of documents, such as blog posts or news articles, that we’d like to divide into natural groups so that we can understand them separately. Topic modeling is a method for unsupervised classification of such documents, similar to clustering on numeric data, which finds natural groups of items even when we’re not sure what we’re looking for.

Please remember to RSVP or you won't be able to get the Zoom link.

Hope you can make it!

Ray

title: R-Ladies Dallas: Flexdashboard tutorial with Kaelen Medeiros  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Happy New Year! For the February edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Kaelen Medeiros as our guest speaker. Kaelen will introduce the topic of flexdashboards.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Let’s Build a Flexdashboard!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: Don’t want to stand up an entire Shiny app to make a quick dashboard, but you know RMarkdown? Enter flexdashboard, which allows you to create a dashboard using a RMarkdown file. In this short workshop, we’ll build a flexdashboard by exploring and visualizing metrics for a pre-specified open dataset. We’ll learn the basics of flexdashboard while brainstorm dashboard design ideas, calculate and display our metrics, and discuss possible deployment options.

Bio: Kaelen is a data scientist at Medidata Solutions where they work as an R programmer on the microservices team. They've also worked at Spring Health, DataCamp, HERE Technologies, and have done a fair amount of R and Shiny consulting on the side. Kaelen has been at various times in their life a film theorist, preschool teacher, test prep tutor, videographer, and nanny before getting a MS in Biostatistics from LSU Health Sciences Center in 2016 and starting work as a statistician and data scientist. Outside of work they enjoy podcasts, cats, aliens, nail polish, and data.

Twitter: twitter.com/kaelen_medeiros

Website: klmedeiros.com

title: R-Ladies Dublin: Intro to machine learning  [Virtual] , Ireland, Europe
description:
Join us for an intro session to machine learning.

Machine Learning is a branch of artificial intelligence focussed on building algorithms that learn from previous data in order to make predictions and decisions based on new data. This talk will cover the basic theory of machine learning and introduce both supervised methods and unsupervised methods such as K-means clustering, KNN classification, logistic regression, decision trees and random forests.

Grab a snack and a drink and dial in on Monday, 15th February, at 5:15PM (GMT)

5:15-5:20 Welcome
5:20-5:30 Introductions
5:30-7:00 Talk and QA: Intro to machine learning by Fiona Murphy

Our speaker Fiona has been working in data analytics for 3 years, starting off her career in a consulting analytics role at EY and about to begin her next chapter as a customer data analyst at Conjura. She graduated from University College Dublin in 2017 with a Bachelor of Science in Statistics and is currently completing a part time master's in Data Analytics with UCD. Fiona specialises in extracting meaningful insights from data using predictive analytics and machine learning methods.

See you on the Internet :)
Jo, Paola and Sapna

title: R-Ladies Belo Horizonte: Introdução ao R - RLadies Belo Horizonte, Brazil, Latin America
description:
Inscrições em: https://www.sympla.com.br/introducao-ao-r---rladies-belo-horizonte__1129323

Objetivo do curso:

Ensinar a você os conceitos básicos do R, uma linguagem de programação popular para análise de dados.

NÍVEL DE HABILIDADE: INICIANTE

Como vai funcionar ?

Desta vez nosso curso está com um formato diferente. Nossas aulas estão gravadas no Youtube e vamos disponibilizar todos os dias um conteúdo e exercícios para o curso. Serão 5 dias com aulas de aproximadamente 40 minutos mais exercícios. No decorrer do curso vamos monitorar os comentários do Youtube para verificar dúvidas e no último dia, vamos fazer uma live para discuti-las. As instruções serão enviadas por e-mail juntamente com o link das aulas e os exercícios propostos.

O que você vai aprender neste curso?

• Introdução a Linguagem e ambiente de programação R
• Explorando o RStudio
• Definindo o diretório de Trabalho
• Primeiros passos na Linguagem R
• Instalando e carregando pacotes no R
• Como obter ajuda na Linguagem R
• Operadores Básicos, Relacionais e Lógicos
• Tipos de variáveis
• Vetores
• Matrizes
• Dataframes
• Listas
• Funções
• Loops

Este curso é para você?

Se você é mulher (cis ou trans) e quer aprender a programar, de forma simples e, principalmente, com uma facilitadora mulher, vem miga que este curso é para você <3

Precisa ter algum conhecimento prévio?

Não, o curso é para iniciantes, inclusive para quem nunca teve experiência com programação.

Vai ter certificado?

Vai sim, todo mundo que responder o formulário final terá direito a um certificado de 6h. O formulário será enviado ao final do curso.

Quem é a facilitadora?

Larissa Sayuri

Carga horária:
6 horas.

Quando?
17 até 24 de Fevereiro , de 19h às 20h00.

O curso é gratuito?
Sim.

Ficou alguma dúvida?
É só enviar para [masked] ;)

Programação:

Aula 1 ( 53 minutos) - 17/02

Explorando R e RStudio
Instalando R e o RStudio

Este viernes 19 de febrero realizaremos la segunda sesión del taller "Expresiones regulares para la limpieza y transformación de datos". El taller estará a cargo de Stephanie Orellana (https://twitter.com/sporella) y Riva Quiroga (https://twitter.com/rivaquiroga).
- SOBRE EL TALLER
Este taller tiene por objetivo que sus participantes se familiaricen con el uso de expresiones regulares (conocidas también como "regex"). Específicamente, abordaremos el potencial que tienen como parte del proceso de limpieza y transformación de datos usando paquetes del Tidyverse.
En esta segunda sesión, profundizaremos en los contenidos vistos en la primera sesión y además veremos cómo podemos utilizar expresiones regulares para limpiar un archivo PDF.
- REQUERIMIENTOS
Si no participaste en la primera parte del taller, te sugerimos revisar el video y los materiales, ya que los ejercicios que realizaremos son una continuación de lo visto en esa sesión: https://github.com/rladieschile/taller-regex-2021/blob/main/README.md
Para este taller es necesario tener una versión de R igual o superior a 3.6 y tener instalados RStudio y los paquetes {tidyverse}, {pdftools}, {janitor} y la versión en desarrollo de {datos}. Esta última se puede instalar desde GitHub con: remotes::install_github("cienciadedatos/datos").
El taller se dictará a través de la plataforma Zoom. Media hora antes del evento enviaremos la clave de acceso a la reunión.
- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
¡Te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies Bogotá: RLadies Bogotá: Agrupamiento de datos (Clustering)  [Virtual] , Colombia, Latin America
description:
En esta sesión de RLadies hablaremos sobre agrupamiento de datos (clustering) que básicamente consiste en encontrar sub-grupos o patrones no tan evidentes en un conjunto de datos. Los métodos de agrupamiento son ampliamente usados en áreas como la medicina, el marketing, el análisis de redes, la psicología, entre otras.
La mayoría de los métodos convencionales de agrupamiento parten de una definición de distancia (o similitud) entre observaciones, pero ¿existe una única manera de comparar observaciones? ¿Cómo podemos elegir el método de agrupamiento más apropiado? ¿Cómo saber en cuántos grupos dividir nuestros datos?

En esta sesión abordaremos estas preguntas, mientras exploramos diferentes librerías en R que nos pueden iluminar el camino para encontrar las respuestas.

Prerrequisitos: Tener instalado RStudio y estas librerías: dplyr, ggplot2, NbClust, factoextra

Imparte: Diana Giraldo
Matemática y magíster en Ingeniería biomédica
Día: Jueves 18 de febrero de 5:30 a 7:30 pm

Link de inscripción para enviarles el link de zoom: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1FgMZ5rBBGQkl1VLxZWkGbWm29-dpnFwpA4ShjaEbg5E/viewform?edit_requested=true

title: Bamako Data Science: Application de machine learning avec Python (2)  [Virtual] , Mali, Africa
description:
Après l'excéllente présentation donnée par Aïssata Cissé en Octobre, nous allons, cette semaine, faire notre retour à Python.
Bréhima Koné, informaticien, va, à son tour, nous montrer une application de machine learning dans Python.
Avec Aïssata, nous nous intéressions au secteur du transport.
Cette fois-ci, le regard sera tourné vers la finance.
Bréhima nous parlera des services d'abonnement à la carte bancaire.
Si vous êtes dans la finance, vous voudriez entendre ce qu'il a à dire.
Si vous êtes détenteur de cartes bancaires...vous avez encore plus de raison d'être là!

Comme d'habitude, sur Zoom à partir de 4:30 PM GMT.

Cheers,
Fousseynou

title: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga: Taller virtual: "Matemáticas en la baraja"  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
group: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
description:
Hola, continuamos con las actividades del grupo, online como toca en la situación actual. Disculpad que en enero el exceso de actividades online lo ha hecho imposible.

Os proponemos un taller muy interesante para comenzar 2021 (y que nos sirva para seguir rodando con el grupo en este año - muchas ganas de hacerlos presenciales): magia y R. El taller se realizará a través de Zoom. Enlace http://bit.ly/rmalaga_magia

Miércoles 24 de febrero a las 19:00. La duración será de una hora y media aproximadamente.

Título: Matemáticas en la baraja

Autor: Manuel Ojeda. Matemático realizando la tesis doctoral en Matemática Aplicada - UMA. Es miembro activo del Circulo de Ilusionistas Malagueños. Mago "malagueño" que ha reunido magia+ R.

Resumen:

Con la excusa de aprender R, Manuel Ojeda Hernández nos introducirá en la magia de las matemáticas. En el taller veremos la teoría de las mezclas, sus tipos y propiedades. Además, trataremos cómo definir funciones simples, usar el paquete {magick} y crear apps en R. Se recomienda tener a mano una baraja de cartas para poder seguir algunos de los experimentos desde casa.
(varita de serie incluida en Rstudio).

Enlace del cartel (difundid la charla, reenviando este correo y/o el enlace):

https://tinyurl.com/grupoRMagiaR

Como siempre, si conocéis a alguien que se apuntó antes en el grupo de usuarios pero no está en Meetup, por favor, indicarle que a partir de ahora trabajamos para coordinarnos usando Meetup.

Manda esta información a interesados en nuestro grupo. Enlace de cartel del grupo de R:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YjmB79A7rASn6ib0YsJH8D6qXnR_XFvc/view?usp=sharing

(difundir el cartel del grupo)

¡Un saludo!

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Transforming Data into Dashboards with Tableau  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
***REGISTER ON EVENTBRITE***
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ocrug-transforming-data-into-dashboards-with-tableau-tickets-141768267705

Develop the practical skills and foundation knowledge to effectively use Tableau to create actionable dashboards.
About this Event
OCRUG understands that these are extraordinary times and we endeavour to keep our events free or very low cost. If you would like to attend the event but the registration fee would put a financial strain on you, please reach out to [masked]. There are a limited number of complimentary tickets available.

# Abstract

This workshop is meant to help data professionals transform raw data into compelling dashboards. We will use Tableau Public to learn how to create dashboard reports from a customer complaints dataset. This data will help you better understand the issues financial customers are experiencing with certain products. During this workshop, you can expect to learn how to use Tableau to ingest, transform, visualize, and use data to design a functional dashboard you can publish and share online. These dashboarding concepts can be used with varying types of datasets so you can quickly transform data into usable information. Attendees can expect to learn how to build dashboards in Tableau Public and use the free software to further develop their data visualization skills.

# Schedule

6:30–6:45: Tableau Public Overview
6:45–7:15: Exploratory Data Analysis
7:15–7:45: Hands-On Exercises
7:45-8:00: Break
8:00–8:15: Dashboard Overview
8:15–8:45: Measures and Visualizations
8:45–9:15: Hands-On Exercises
9:15–9:30: Tableau or Analytics QA

# Venue

This event will be held on Zoom. You will need a Zoom account in order to join. Before the event, the Zoom link will be emailed to you.

# Organizers

This event is being brought to you by the Orange Country R Users Group (OCRUG) https://www.meetup.com/OC-RUG/

# Sponsors

This event is sponsored by the University of California, Paul Merage School of Business. https://merage.uci.edu/

# Code of Conduct

https://github.com/ocrug/hackathon-2019-05/blob/master/code-of-conduct.md

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Book club  - Text Mining with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Are you looking to improve our R skills? Come just us for a book club. It will be headed up by John Peach. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly. If you cannot make a commitment to attend, please wait until the next book club starts. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader. The leader should prepare a summary of the material that was read and present it to the group.

We will meet each week, Monday evening between 6:30 and 8:00 PM for six weeks.

Book: Title: Text Mining with R
Online: https://www.tidytextmining.com/
Dead Tree: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1491981652/

Signing up: When you sign-up you will be placed on the waiting list. We always have a lot of interest but the book club is a significant commitment. The coordinator will confirm your commitment. Please make sure that you get meet-up emails.

Session 1:
* C1: The Tidy Text Format
* C2: Sentiment Analysis with Tidy Data
* Exercise

Session 2:
* C3: Analyzing Word and Document Frequency: tf-idf
* C4: Relationships Between Words: N-grams and Correlations
* Exercise

Session 3:
* C5: Converting to and from Nontidy Formats
* C6: Topic Modeling

Session 4:
* C7: Case Study: Comparing Twitter Archives
* Exercise

Session 5:
* C8: Case Study: Mining NASA Metadata
* Exercise

Session 6:
* C9: Case Study: Analyzing Usenet Text
* Exercise

title: Bengaluru R UseR Group (BRUG): Data Science with R - First Meetup of 2021  [Virtual] , India, Asia
description:
This is the first Bengaluru R Meetup of 2021 (and also one after almost a year). This is our attempt to see how we can organize a meetup in this online-only world and see if it benefits us. Hence, we're keeping it lean with 2 hours event.

Agenda:

* Session 1 - Mapping with {tmap} - Saurav Ghosh
* Session 2 - TBD

Looking forward to a good start :)

Comment here if you've any questions!

FAQs & Guidelines:
* Most of our sessions are beginner-friendly so anyone can attend.
* Please be respectful while asking questions or interacting with other members.
* Please be mindful before sharing your personal details with others who attend the meetup.

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Using & Expanding the NLP Models Hub  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register Here: https://tinyurl.com/2v5uhwp5

The NLP Models Hub which powers the Spark NLP and NLU libraries takes a different approach than the hubs of other libraries like TensorFlow, PyTorch, and Hugging Face. While it also provides an easy-to-use interface to find, understand, and reuse pre-trained models, it focuses on providing production-grade state-of-the-art models for each NLP task instead of a comprehensive archive.

This implies a higher quality bar for accepting community contributions to the NLP Models Hub - in terms of automated testing, level of documentation, and transparency of accuracy metrics and training datasets. This webinar shows how you can make the most of it, whether you're looking to easily reuse models or contribute new ones.

Register Here: https://tinyurl.com/2v5uhwp5

title: Inland Northwest R User Group (INRUG): Using R to teach population ecology  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Speaker: Dr. Gary Chang

Title: Using R to teach population ecology, from exponential dynamics to epidemiological models

Abstract: A variety of mathematical models are used to teach population ecology and can be implemented in R. Professor Chang will discuss how he used R to build models ranging from projections of a single population, to numerical solutions of systems of ordinary differential equations using the deSolve package. He will also reflect his experience of using R to teach Biology majors.

Profile of Speaker: Gary Chang, Ph.D., is an Associate Professor of Biology at Gonzaga University. He teaches courses such as ecology, entomology, and pollinator conservation, and he conducts research with students on bee behavior.

Upon RSVPing, you should receive the link to the meeting. If you don't please send me an email at [masked] for more information.

Alison loves teaching, and has led advanced workshops on data science communication and machine learning at rstudio::conf, R / Medicine, and R in Pharma. title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: The Magical Code Menu in RStudio  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our March Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

For many R users, RStudio is just an excellent environment to write their code. Compared to the Rgui program included with the R installer, RStudio offers a clean, organized way to write code, view results, and organize their projects. However, RStudio offers many more features to help you out. In this presentation we're going to do a deep dive into the 'Code' menu which has many tools for writing cleaner, more reusable code and making certain tedious tasks easy. The end goal is to write better, more reusable code with less work.

Kenneth Fairchild is a Senior Consultant at Sawtooth Software where he specializes in Conjoint market research surveys. Kenneth's R interests are in automatic tasks, optimizing workflows, and generating high-quality deliverables for end-clients.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Stacked Ensemble Modeling with Tidy Data Principles  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our April Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Stacked ensemble modeling is a statistical modeling technique that involves training a model to combine the outputs of many constituent models. The technique has been shown to increase predictive performance in a variety of settings. This talk will introduce {stacks}, a free and open-source R software package for stacked ensemble modeling that aligns with tidy data principles. The package’s functionality is closely aligned with the {tidymodels}, a collection of packages providing a unified interface to diverse statistical modeling techniques.

Simon Couch is a developer on open source R packages for statistical modeling. He is currently an undergraduate studying statistics at Reed College and formerly an intern at RStudio. Simon was awarded the 2021 John M. Chambers Statistical Software Award for {stacks}.

Dr. Rachael Tatman is a senior developer advocate at Rasa, where she helps developers use open source software to build great conversational AI projects. Before that she was at Kaggle (part of Google) and completed a PhD in Linguistics.

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by WhyR: Towards automating Time Series Forecasting Using R  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

- channel: youtube.com/c/WhyRFoundationVideos
- date: every Thursday 7:00 pm (UTC+0)
- format: one 45 minutes long stream + 10 minutes for Q&A
- comments: ask questions on YouTube live chat
- join Why R? Slack whyr.pl/slack/
- LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/why-r
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/whyrconf/

(In the event of any technical difficulties, please consult our twitter page for updates)

Title: “Towards automating Time Series Forecasting Using R”

Abstract:

Both complex and dynamic evolving nature of time series data make forecasting among one of the most important and challenging tasks in time series analysis. Typical methods for forecasting are designed to model time-evolving dependencies between data observations. However, it is generally accepted that none of them is universally valid for every application. Therefore, methods for learning heterogeneous ensembles by combining a diverse set of forecasts together appear as a promising solution to tackle this task. Ensemble construction is based on several steps including base models generation, pruning and aggregation. The goal of this talk is to present the most promising R packages/solutions for automating adaptive ensemble models construction for online time series forecasting by reducing the human intervention in the ML-loop

Short Bio:

I am Amal Saadallah and I work as a research assistant in the artificial intelligence group of the TU Dortmund, within B3 subproject (Data Mining on Sensor Data of Automated Processes) of the Collaborative Research Center SFB 876 (Providing Information by Resource-Constrained Data Analysis). My main research work is about adaptive ensemble methods for online learning, time series analysis and forecasting and sensor-simulation data mining. I am also investigating industry 4.0 related applications, more specifically for machining processes. Hence, one of the major research directions in B3 is the combination of machine learning methods and process simulation systems for predictive maintenance and quality control of milling processes.

My list of publications can also give you the big picture of my research activities:

https://www-ai.cs.tu-dortmund.de/PERSONAL/saadallah.html

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by WhyR: officeverse: creating Word and PowerPoint documents with R  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

- channel: youtube.com/c/WhyRFoundationVideos
- date: every Thursday 7:00 pm (Irish Time)
- format: one 45 minutes long stream + 10 minutes for Q&A
- MC: Lais Carvalho & Guests
- comments: ask questions on YouTube live chat
- join Why R? Slack whyr.pl/slack/
- LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/why-r
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/whyrconf/

(In case of technical difficulties, please consult our twitter page for updates)

## Abstract

officeverse : a set of packages to ease the production of Word and PowerPoint documents

The officer package has been developed to facilitate the production of Word documents and PowerPoint presentations with R.

The initial project was to offer an alternative solution to SAS ODS for tabular and graphical reports produced in Word for one of my clients. The range of functionalities has expanded and some very interesting extensions have been created. There is the officedown package that increases the layout capabilities of R Markdown when the output is Word, the rvg package to create editable vector graphics, the flextable package to make nice tables.

In this presentation, you will see how to use the package to produce PowerPoint presentations and Word documents. Its role as a foundation for other packages and new documentation will be discussed. It will also be an opportunity for David to present the officedown package for the first time.

## Speaker

David Gohel is the founder of ArData, a French company providing R expertise, R training and consulting in data sciences. He is the author of R packages, most popular are officer, flextable, rvg and ggiraph.

He is a data scientist and software engineer. His professional experiences led him to face many challenges related to the data of organizations, which he has always managed with solutions involving R software.

title: R-Ladies Bari: SELF LEADERSHIP: PER ESSERE UN VERO LEADER PRIMA BISOGNA CONOSCERSI [Workshop]  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
Eccoci con il nuovo meetup #RLadiesItaly!

Il nuovo evento sarà con Nancy Cooklin. A partire da una lunga e approfondita esperienza di lavoro a stretto contatto con le persone, in piccoli e grandi gruppi e organizzazioni, e dalle diverse culture e generazioni, Nancy Cooklin, coach, counselor e formatrice, ha creato un modello chiamato “Human Leadership”.

In questo momento più che mai l’aspetto “Human” è diventato centrale sia nella vita professionale che in quella personale. La chiave sta nell'essere focalizzati e forti emotivamente. In questo modello ci sono 4 aree tra le quali Nancy ci guiderà: consapevolezza, creatività, coraggio e pensiero sistemico.
Avere chiarezza su chi siamo e cosa ci guida accresce la nostra autostima e ci permette di relazionarci in modo autentico e coerente con chi siamo e cosa vogliamo.

Dopo questo workshop:

- Ti sentirai più allineata o concentrata così da saper prendere decisioni più facilmente.
- Prederai consapevolezza delle leve che ti portano ad agire
- Capirai come funziona il meccanismo del cambiamento e perché a volte cambiare è più difficile che non cambiare
- Riconoscerai l’importanza della tua storia per andare verso il futuro più libera di fare le tue scelte
- Saprai comunicare con gli altri in modo efficace
- Capirai l’importanza dell’autenticità nel mondo di oggi, sia a livello personale che professionale

Le persone ti scelgono per quello che sei, non per quello che fai!

Ci vediamo presto!

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Making Extra Great Slides with xaringan, xaringanthemer and xaringanExtra  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
This month we look at the xaringan presentation ecosystem.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack.

About the Talk:
The xaringan package by Yihui Xie lets R users and R Markdown authors easily blend data, text, plots and htmlwidgets into beautiful HTML presentations that look great on the web, in print, and on screens. In addition to demonstrating how to go from R Markdown to web-based slides with xaringan, in this talk I'll show you how to completely customize the appearance of your slides with xaringanthemer, a package that lets you quickly create a complete slide theme from only a few color choices. Then we'll go beyond appearances with a variety of addins and extensions from the xaringanExtra package, including: a tiled slide overview, editable slides, embedded webcam videos, tabbed panels, extra styles, shareable and embeddable slides, animations, and real time slide broadcasting.

About Garrick:
Garrick Aden-Buie is a Data Science Educator at RStudio and lives in sunny St. Petersburg, Florida. His passion is to combine creative coding with programming education, using code to build tools that teach coding to new and advanced R users alike. Like tidyexplain: a project that used ggplot2 and gganimate to reimagine database operations as colorful flying boxes instead of the typical Venn diagrams. Garrick has developed a number of open source addins and packages for RStudio—such as regexplain, shrtcts and rsthemes—and is always easily distracted by projects that combine R Markdown and online learning or teaching.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EST and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

Note: This is an extended version of the {ggplot2} talk that Cédric gave recently at the Outlier Conference.

[Bio]
Cédric is a computational ecologist by training and a data visualization designer by heart with more than 10 years of hypothesis-driven research experience. For all his projects, no matter if scientific, client or personal projects, he uses {ggplot2} to create powerful and aesthetically pleasing visualizations.

[About]
This event is organized by the Oslo useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/) and will be co-hosted by the Skåne useR! Group (https://www.meetup.com/Skane-R-User-Group/).

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: March meeting: Teach me how to make a package!  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
For our March session, we come together for the second edition of our original experimental meetup format, "Teach me {x}".

This time, Janine will bring some simple example code that she has already written and now wants to export as an R package. One small problem: She has never written a package before, so she will need the help of experts (i. e. you!) to build it! Come and join us for this non-expert talk... an "un-webinar" if you will.

As always, our session is open to useRs of all backgrounds and at all levels of expertise. So if you're new to packages yourself, don't worry! This will be an opportunity to tune in, ask questions and try out package authoring as well.

title: R-Ladies Philly: Virtual Happy Hour  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description: Join R-Ladies Philly for a virtual happy hour on Thursday, March 4th from 6 to 7PM EST. BYO beverages. Be prepared to mingle! Over the course of the hour everyone will have two short one-on-one conversations and five small group discussions. No worries if you join late or need to leave early but the event will end at 7PM sharp.

title: R-Ladies Philly: 2021 Datathon Kickoff: Exploring Judicial Patterns  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us for a 6-week datathon focused on exploring judicial patterns in Philadelphia courts! We have partnered with the Judge Accountability Table (JAT; https://judgeaccountabilitytable.org/about/) to help them explore, stratify, and visualize a complex dataset related to public court dockets for defendants in Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania. We will be working on a deidentified subset of these data in order to:

- better understand the judicial system through data
- hone our data science and R skills (there will be ways to contribute for people of all levels of experience with R)
- get our hands dirty and our heads spinning with rich and messy real-world data (spoiler alert: we will not be analyzing sepal.length and petal.width)
- work together, network, and make (new) friends in the data world!
- have fun nerding out together over data :)

Rough Agenda:

- Intro to RLadies Philly datathons
- Partner introduction
- Logistics
- Teams setup and work kickoff

Stay tuned for more updates!

title: R-Ladies Brisbane: Using R to analyse step count data: common pitfalls and how to get over them  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
*What are we going to learn:
Interested in analysing health data (like step count)? Not sure how to go about it using R? This talk will cover some common issues researchers and data scientists might encounter when dealing with longitudinal step count data and how R can be used to help with the analysis.

*Who is going to present:
Ly is a Digital Health Scientist and Consultant. Ly is passionate about helping people lead a healthy and happy life. Her current PhD research at Macquarie University leverages how to use AI & mobile technologies to promote healthy behaviour (like physical activity). Ly is a big fan of R and Github, and her favourite packages are ggplot2 and dplyr. Ly loves to share her love of R and learn about it with other people. While Ly is not busy with her R codes, she likes to hang out with her plant babies (all 56 of them) or doing some embroidery.

* When are we meeting?
The talk will start at 5:00 pm for approximately 1.5 hours.

************The presentation will start at 5:00 pm********************
* Where are we meeting?
We will meet virtually using Zoom, the link will be visible to people who RSVP.

* What else is needed?
This will be an interactive ~90 min presentation. If you would like to follow along in RStudio please make sure you have installed the following before the session:

R - https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/base/
RStudio - https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/
Required packages: " dplyr ", ggplot2" and " RMarkdown "

We look forward to seeing you there!

title: R-Ladies Goiânia: Introdução ao R  [Virtual] , Brazil, Latin America
description:
Heey, tudo bem?

Estamos muito felizes com a sua participação.

Aproveite o curso. Aproveite essa oportunidade! Este evento foi pensado com muito carinho para você.

O que você vai aprender?

Durante este curso serão abordados os seguintes tópicos:

Introdução ao RStudio;
Primeiros passos em R;
Operadores matemáticos, relacionais e lógicos;
Variáveis;
Objetos;
Vetores, matrizes e listas;
Dataframes;
Funções.

Quais pacotes vão ser utilizados ?

library(stats)
library(base)
library(tidyverse)
library(readr, readxls)

Sobre o Projeto Enigma

O projeto Enigma busca tornar visível o papel feminino na área da computação, resgatando as contribuições significativas de algumas mulheres de uma forma diferenciada, que provoque o pensamento do fruidor. Não pretende-se reproduzir as visibilidades que estas personagens já têm, mas fazer uma provocação, desacomodando o pensamento para que as invisibilidades, que ainda persistem, se tornem visíveis. As doações serão voltadas a reforma de artigos doados ao projeto como computadores, teclados e entre outros objetos do universo computacional.

Para saber mais sobre este projeto lindo acesse https://www.ufrgs.br/enigma/

E aí? Topa?

Link de inscrição: https://www.sympla.com.br/introducao-ao-r__1136808

Dúvidas frequentes:

CERTIFICADOS! - O certificado de 4h do evento será enviado para o seu e-mail. Caso você não receba ao final do evento, escreva para [masked].

MATERIAIS! - Os materiais utilizados no nosso curso (apresentação, scripts) serão disponibilizados através do nosso GitHub .

Dicas importantes para melhor aproveitamento do evento

(1°) Procure conectar o seu computador no cabo de rede, evitando instabilidades na transmissão;
(2°) Pré-configure a sua câmera e microfone antes de entrar no evento pois será útil para as interações com a professora em caso de dúvidas!
(3°) Prepare seu ambiente, aquela caneca de café, garrafa de água e os fones de ouvido, melhores companheiros para se concentrar e mergulhar de cabeça nessa experiência!
(4°) Não guarde esse conhecimento apenas para você, compartilhe com seus amigos e redes sociais marcando a gente no instagram @rladiesgyn.

Você faz parte desse compromisso

Lembre-se que o Código de Conduta também se estende à versão online de nossos eventos e não será tolerada qualquer forma de assédios ou intimidações de qualquer participante, seja audiência, palestrantes, colaboradores, ou quaisquer membros da comunidade.

A gente brilha TOGETHER!

title: R-Ladies Bucharest: R-Ladies Bucharest #16: Julia Silge - Three reasons to choose Tidymodels  [Virtual] , Romania, Europe
description:
Join us for a new session on the 23rd of March, 7PM EET ! We continue our meetups with #goodRvibes and a speaker you'll definitely enjoy!

Three reasons to use tidymodels with Julia Silge

Modeling and machine learning in R involve a bewildering array of heterogeneous packages, and establishing good statistical practice is challenging in any language. The tidymodels (tidymodels.org) collection of packages offers a consistent, flexible framework for your modeling and machine learning work to address these problems. In this talk, we’ll focus on three specific reasons to consider using tidymodels. We will start with model characteristics themselves, move to the wise management of your data budget, and finish with feature engineering.

Julia Silge is a data scientist and software engineer at RStudio PBC where she works on open source modeling tools. She is an author, an international keynote speaker, and a real-world practitioner focusing on data analysis and machine learning practice. Julia loves text analysis, making beautiful charts, and communicating about technical topics with diverse audiences.

Registration is free, but mandatory via meetup. We shall meet on zoom, and the link will be updated on the day of the event ( PIN for entrance should be sent by email ~2hours before meeting start).

title: R-Ladies Twin Cities: Building and using lmeresampler for hierarchical linear models  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description: Jenna K. spent the summer of 2020 working on the R package lmeresampler (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/lmeresampler/index.html). title: R-Ladies Irvine: Undergraduate Research with Graduate Topics & Experimental Design with Tidyverse  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, March 16, 6:30-8:00 pm (Pacific)
6:30 - Welcome and Networking
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - Undergraduate Research with Graduate Level Topics
7:25 - Q&A
7:30 - Modernizing Design of Experiment Output with Tidyverse
7:55 - Q&A
8:00 - Meeting Adjourned

# Undergraduate Research with Graduate Level Topics
Speaker: Jessica Jaynes, PhD
Assistant Professor of Statistics, Department of Mathematics, CSU Fullerton

Bio: Dr. Jessica Jaynes is an Assistant Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics at California State University, Fullerton. She received her Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of California, Los Angeles. Her area of expertise includes design of experiments, statistical methods and applications, survey methods, and discrete choice experiments. Her recent projects include the development of a new class of experimental designs that provide higher efficiency, more in-depth analyses, and require a shorter time to run. This research has led to multiple interdisciplinary funded projects.

Abstract: As science and technology progress, this often calls for innovation in methodological and theoretical development of statistical experimental design, an essential aspect for research in any discipline. This research concentrates on the close connection between statistics and medicine, and the development of novel experiments to maximize efficiency, while minimizing time and costs. The focus of this talk will be on an application of an undergraduate research project using a novel experimental design known as an Orthogonal Array Composite Design (OACD) with applications to KB oral cancer. In particular, this talk will highlight the methods and applications that undergraduate students contributed to. Furthermore, various takeaways will be presented in terms of tips, challenges, and benefits in working with undergraduate students. sources.

# Modernizing Design of Experiment Output with Tidyverse
Speaker: Jose Toledo
Graduate Student, Statistics Dept, CSU Fullerton

Bio: Jose is currently in his last semester in the Master’s in statistics program at California State University, Fullerton (CSUF), where he is also a teaching associate. Additionally, he is a part-time data analyst at Southern California Coast Water Project. His research interest is in the field of Design of Experiments, where he has worked on projects such as drug combination treatments for KB oral cancer and recently in tuberculosis. During his summer breaks he enjoys mentoring undergraduate students in local community colleges and providing them research opportunities early in their education.

Abstract: Most Design of Experiment (DoE) experts will agree that using FrF2 is the most comprehensive R package for generating two-level factorial designs as well as Plackett-Burman type screening designs. Similarly, for sequential optimization with first order and second order response surface models, that offer optimization approaches like steepest ascent and visualization of the response function for linear model objects, the package rsm is highly recommended. However, their graphical outputs are limited and can benefit from the current “trends” in R such as implementing graphics using ggplot2. This talk will focus on the development of an R package, ggDoE, which focuses on the visualization of DoE using ggplot2. Examples will be taken from a TB drug combination experiment and demonstrate the output of commonly used methods in DoE. These methods include but are not limited to: factorial effect plots, half-normal plots, Lenth’s method, fitting second-order models and their corresponding contour plots.

# Meeting Materials
All meeting materials will be sent to registered attendees after the event.

title: R-Ladies Utrecht: Manipulating text in R: effective use of Regular Expressions (regex)  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
String manipulation is a key tool in data wrangling and yet one that is not often discussed or mentioned. Regular expressions or regex allow us to create patterns that help us find or modify strings/text. Don't you think that such a tool is very valuable?!! Do you want to learn how to use regex effectively in R?

In this meet-up Barbara Vreede and Tessa Pronk will be introducing us to the use of regular expressions in R and organizing some nice activities where we can practice!

The program will look like this:

19:30 - Welcome and introduction to regex
20:00 - Breakout rooms 1: crossword
20:10 - Discussion of crossword, solution and lessons
20:20 - Breakout rooms 2: webscrapping
20:40 - results and lessons
20:50 - Closing remarks

REQUIREMENTS:

- Basic knowledge in R is assumed.
- Preferentially having R and RStudio installed and ready to use so you can follow along with the activities.

ABOUT THE PRESENTERS:

- Barbara Vreede: https://www.linkedin.com/in/barbara-vreede-69986a1b/?originalSubdomain=nl

- Tessa Pronk: https://www.kwrwater.nl/experts-expertises/experts/tessa-pronk/

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {R-Ladies Toolbox Series} Part 3: Reproducibility   [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
R-Ladies Toolbox Series - Essentials for women and minority genders in academia, science and data analysis presents:

Reproducibility by Charles Grey (R-Ladies Remote)

Talk Abstract:
As scientists, it's desirable to demonstrate to others (including our future selves) that our computational scientific work validates the claims we make in published research. Being able to reproduce the work is a key component of easily validating an analysis, as well as extending the work. Reproducibility is not as simple, however, as sharing the code and data that produced our analysis. We must consider how our data and algorithms are understood, variables defined, etc. Our code needs to be accessible and interoperable. There is much guidance about best practice, but this is often overwhelming for those of us who are not from formal computer science training. In this talk I share the story of how I attempted good enough practice in my doctoral thesis, and found even this was simply too much to achieve. Indeed, despite failing to achieve good enough scientific practice in any aspect of reproducibility, I discovered a delightful world of scientific workflows in R that make every day just that bit easier now. Failing at reproducible science in R is the best we can aim for; we will never achieve best practice in every aspect of reproducibility, and if we failed, then we tried. Through this process we discover useful tools to make the next time easier.

BIO:
Charles T. Gray is a postdoc with the evidence synthesis lab at Newcastle University. She is currently specialising in Bayesian network meta-analysis in Cochrane intervention reviews. She has three degrees: arts, music, and mathematics. None of these prepared her for her interdisciplinary computational metascience doctoral thesis in R.

Calling all students, academics, and women in science! R-Ladies Freiburg presents a five-part guest series aimed at women and gender minorities in academia, science and data analysis, from first semester students to tenured researchers. Leading R-Ladies from around the world will lead us through the most fundamental steps to studying and working in academia, from analyzing results, to presenting them clearly, ensuring their reproducibility, and keeping track of all your changes. The series will close with a panel discussion from women around the world, who will speak about their experiences with science.

This series is funded by the “Pädagogische Hochschule Freiburg”, the University of Education in Freiburg.

Participants who take part in all five meetups can receive a certificate of participation.

Everyone is welcome to join and we hope for a warm exchange between students and researchers, as well as R-Ladies from the wider community.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {Part 3: Wrangling} From Zero to (s)Hero: Multi-part intro to R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Just getting involved with R or want to level up your skills? Have you used base-R but are still trying to wrap your head around the tidyverse "pipe" (%>%)? Have a messy dataset and don't know where to start? Seen beautiful visualizations on Twitter and want to make your own?

If you’ve answered ‘yes’ to at least one of these questions, fear no more! In this monthly workshop series, we will walk you through the fundamental uses of tidyverse and ggplot at your own pace with the help of hands-on exercises. Tidyverse and ggplot are a classic combination of R packages that allow you to "wrangle" your unwieldy data into whatever shape you need and creative beautiful and informative visualizations.

Over the course of this series, you will learn the most useful features of R Studio and R Markdown, how to read in and explore data, and transform it into a shape that's easy to work with. You will be able to create new columns and summary tables, subset interesting rows or columns, and combine and reshape dataframes. We will also dive into ggplot, one of the best tools for creating great-looking bar charts, scatterplots, and more!

This is (currently) a five-part series, aimed at total beginners and/or people with some experience in base-R or tidyverse who are looking to freshen up or expand their skills. Feel free to join at any point, we will briefly review the previous topic at the beginning of each session.

January 20th {Part 1}: The R & R-Studio ABCs (packages, files, data types & basic data exploration)
February 17th {Part 2}: Tidy data & introduction to data wrangling (tibbles, renaming, reordering, subsetting)
March 17th {Part 3}: Data wrangling with dplyr (new columns, if-else statements, summary tables, joining dataframes)
April 21st {Part 4}: Introduction to visualizations with ggplot (line graphs, bar charts, scatterplots, histograms, and more!)
May 19th {Part 5}: Advanced topics in wrangling and ggplot (pivoting, ggplot style options, etc.)

Please install R and R-Studio before joining: https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/starting.html

Image by the amazing @allison_horst: https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations
